title: 103_s2356
content:
The Act is titled the "Commission on the Advancement of Women in the Science and Engineering Work Forces Act". The Congress acknowledges the underrepresentation of women in science and engineering fields, citing higher rates of unemployment and underemployment for women compared to men. They recognize artificial barriers in recruitment and advancement, while also noting the increasing awareness of the benefits of diverse workforces in academia, industry, and government. The White House Task Force and Federal Coordinating Council initiatives have raised awareness about the underrepresentation of women in science and engineering fields and the need to eliminate barriers to their recruitment and advancement. Establishing a commission to address these issues would further emphasize the importance of removing these barriers. The curr_chunk focuses on promoting the recruitment, retention, and advancement of women in science and engineering fields in the United States. It aims to increase workforce diversity, address projected shortfalls in the next 20 years, and encourage the replication of successful programs by universities, corporations, and federal agencies. The Commission on the Advancement of Women in the Science and Engineering Workforces is established. The Commission's duty is to promote recruitment, retention, and advancement of women in these fields. The Commission will study the underrepresentation of women in science and engineering fields, assess their readiness for career advancement, examine employer practices, and identify barriers to women's progress in academia, industry, and government. The Commission will study the underrepresentation of women in science and engineering fields, assess their readiness for career advancement, examine employer practices, and identify barriers to women's progress in academia, industry, and government. They will also describe employment situations for women scientists and engineers compared to men, compile research on successful recruitment, retention, and advancement practices for women in these fields, and examine other relevant issues as determined by the Commission. The Commission will issue recommendations for government, academia, and private industry to support the recruitment, retention, and advancement of women in science and engineering. SEC. 5. MEMBERSHIP. The Commission consists of 18 members appointed by various leaders in the House of Representatives and the Senate. The Commission consists of 18 members appointed by various leaders in the House of Representatives and the Senate, including the minority leader of the Senate and the Director of the Office of Science and Technology Policy. Initial appointments must meet specific qualifications related to diversity, executive experience, and expertise in employment issues. Additionally, political affiliation is limited to ensure a balanced representation. Each member of the Commission is appointed for life, with vacancies filled in the same manner as the original appointment. Members receive compensation at the maximum rate of pay under title 5, United States Code, for each day of duty. If a member appointed due to government employment ceases to be an officer or employee, they may continue for up to 60 days. Each member of the Commission is appointed for life and receives compensation at the maximum rate of pay under title 5, United States Code. Members are engaged in performing duties for the Commission, including attending meetings and conferences, and travel. Federal employees serving on the Commission cannot receive additional pay, allowances, or benefits. Members receive travel expenses and per diem in lieu of subsistence. A majority of members constitutes a quorum for business transactions, and the Director of the Office of Science and Technology Policy serves as the Chairperson of the Commission. The Technology Policy Chairperson of the Commission must hold meetings at least 5 times before completing reports. After the report in section 8(b), the Commission must meet once or twice for the report in section 8(c). Members not federal employees cannot receive additional compensation. The curr_chunk states that an officer or employee of the Federal Government is not considered a federal employee except for specific purposes related to tort claims and compensation for work injuries. SEC. 6. DIRECTOR AND STAFF OF COMMISSION; EXPERTS AND CONSULTANTS. The Commission shall have a Director appointed by the Chairperson, who will be paid at a specified rate. The Chairperson can appoint additional staff and determine their pay. The Director and staff may be appointed and paid without following certain civil service laws, but their pay cannot exceed a certain limit. The Commission may procure temporary services at rates not exceeding the maximum annual rate of basic pay. Federal agencies can detail personnel to assist the Commission on a reimbursable basis. SEC. 7. POWERS OF COMMISSION. The Commission has the authority to hold hearings, take testimony, receive evidence, administer oaths, and obtain information from government agencies. Members and agents can take actions authorized by the Commission, and the Commission can accept gifts, bequests, and devises. The Commission has the authority to accept gifts, bequests, or devises of money and property, which will be deposited in the Treasury for disbursement. They can also use the United States mails and receive administrative support services from the Administrator of General Services on a reimbursable basis. Additionally, the Commission may contract with and compensate as provided in appropriations Acts. The Commission has the authority to contract with government and private agencies for research purposes under appropriations Acts. SEC. 8. REPORTS. The Commission must submit a Status Report within 1 year of initial appointments, a Recommendation Report within 18 months, and a Follow-Up Report thereafter. After submitting the Recommendation Report, the Commission must provide a Follow-Up Report to the President and Congress, identifying implemented recommendations and including any additional relevant information. SEC. 9. CONSTRUCTION; USE OF INFORMATION OBTAINED.

Non-Federal entities are not required to provide personnel policy information to the Commission. Information obtained cannot be used in employment litigation.

SEC. 10. TERMINATION.

The Commission will end one year after submitting the required report.

SEC. 11. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS.

Appropriations are authorized for fiscal years 1995-1997 to implement this Act.
